item.title: Sarah Everard: Met Police chief will not resign over vigil scenes
item.description: The home secretary wants an independent investigation into the handling of a vigil for Sarah Everard.

item.title: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe in Tehran court on new charge
item.description: The British-Iranian woman faces new charges, a week after being freed from a five-year prison term.

item.title: Covid-19: Dutch police break up anti-lockdown protest
item.description: Police used water cannon and mounted officers to clear anti-government demonstrators in The Hague.

item.title: Myanmar protests: Protesters killed in bloody Yangon crackdown
item.description: More protesters and a police officer are reported dead elsewhere as anti-coup protests continue.

item.title: Covid-19: Charities urge vulnerable people to book vaccines
item.description: People with underlying health conditions who have yet to get their jab are being encouraged to do so.

item.title: Government defends plans for noise limit at protests
item.description: A bill limiting noise at demonstrations will only affect "very disruptive" events, a minister says.

item.title: Covid-19: NI to keep using AstraZeneca jab after Irish suspension
item.description: The Republic of Ireland stops using the vaccine after reports of blood clotting in adults in Norway.

item.title: Scotland hospitality urges lockdown levels rethink
item.description: Industry groups wants Scotland to mirror England's reopening plans by extending opening times and naming dates.

item.title: Covid-19: British Airways plans app-based travel pass
item.description: People who have had both jabs will be able to register their status on BA's smartphone app.

item.title: Six Nations 2021: Ireland beat Scotland 27-24 via late Johnny Sexton penalty
item.description: Johnny Sexton knocks over a late penalty as Ireland survive a surge from Scotland to eke out a hectic Six Nations victory at Murrayfield.

item.title: Sixteen in hospital as Isle of Man Covid cases pass 800
item.description: It marks highest number of hospital admissions during the currrent outbreak as new cases rise by 44.

item.title: Pregnancy in lockdown: The babies born into a pandemic
item.description: Five mothers share what it was like to be pregnant and give birth during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Zimbabwe's 16-year-old motocross champion on 'beating the boys'
item.description: Tanya Muzinda has taken on the male-dominated world of motocross - becoming her country's off-road circuits champion.

item.title: Mother's Day quadruple delight for NI grandmother
item.description: Marie Lindsay's two daughters each gave birth to a set of twins just a few months apart last year.

item.title: Your pictures on the theme of 'I made this'
item.description: A selection of striking images from our readers on this week's theme.

item.title: Almost 100 and still dancing
item.description: Dinkie Flowers, who is about to turn 100, says it is important "not to sit on your bum all day".

item.title: Formula 1 legend Murray Walker in his own words
item.description: Legendary Formula 1 commentator Murray Walker, who has died aged 97, explains why working in the sport meant so much to him, and friends and colleagues pay their own tributes.

item.title: Grammys 2021: Seven things to look out for - and how to watch the ceremony
item.description: Everything you need to know about Sunday's show, from who's performing to potential controversies.

item.title: Sri Lanka adoption: The babies who were given away
item.description: Thousands of newborns were sold to families in Europe. Decades later, Sri Lankan mothers are trying to find them.

item.title: Celeste: How the UK singer made a 'secret' Oscars film song
item.description: The singer-songwriter on movie music magic, award recognition and proving herself as a No.1 artist.

item.title: Phone scammers: 'Give me £1,000 to stop calling you'
item.description: The rise of scam calls seems relentless - but can anything be done about them?

item.title: Covid has 'heightened' eating anxieties, say experts
item.description: The pandemic has been particularly challenging for people like Phoenix, say eating disorder experts.

item.title: Mother's Day: How sustainable are the flowers you buy?
item.description: Most people are "oblivious" to the environmental impact of shop-bought cut flowers, a florist says.

item.title: Is there an algorithm for the perfect biryani?
item.description: A new book argues that cooking, at its heart, is chemistry. And algorithms are the key to it.

item.title: Lamela scores 'rabona' and is sent off as Arsenal come back to beat Spurs
item.description: Tottenham's Erik Lamela scores a stunning rabona goal but is later sent off as Arsenal come from behind to win a thrilling derby.

item.title: India cruise to victory over sloppy England in second T20
item.description: England suffer a chastening seven-wicket defeat by a resurgent India in the second Twenty20 in Ahmedabad.

item.title: Kerr hat-trick fires Chelsea to League Cup final rout of Bristol City
item.description: Chelsea retain the Women's League Cup with a record-breaking final win over Bristol City at Vicarage Road.

item.title: Six Nations 2021: Scotland 24-27 Ireland highlights
item.description: Watch highlights of Ireland's win against Scotland as a late Johnny Sexton penalty seals their 27-24 victory at Murrayfield.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: 'Vaccine passports': Will I need one for going out, work and travel?
item.description: The government is reviewing whether venues can ask for proof of vaccination or a negative test.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: What are the Brazil, South Africa and UK variants and will vaccines work?
item.description: More cases are being found in the UK, including a variant first seen in Brazil.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Wales and Scotland have announced the easing of restrictions on people meeting

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: The government says it may still be too early to book summer holidays abroad.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Covid: What are the new rules for schools?
item.description: All students in England can now return to classrooms, but how will Covid testing work?

item.title: What happens if I don't get the Covid vaccine?
item.description: There are multiple coronavirus vaccines being rolled out in countries across the UK and around the world. What happens if you don't want it?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 23 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for new variants?
item.description: The government hopes "surge" testing will reduce transmission of new variants of Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pubs, hairdressers and gyms open?
item.description: Lockdown is being eased in England. When will services like hairdressers, pubs and gyms open?

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the test-and-trace system work?
item.description: MPs have said the government's test-and-trace system is too expensive and hasn't helped fight the pandemic.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Two approved Covid vaccines are being rolled out across the UK. So when might you get one?

item.title: What are the new rules for testing and hotel quarantine?
item.description: Travellers going to and from the UK face a growing number of restrictions.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Coronavirus testing: How to do a lateral flow test at home
item.description: Coronavirus lateral flow tests are free and provide a quick result within 30 minutes. But how do you do one?

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the care home visiting rules in England?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to relatives wanting to visit care homes.

item.title: How could children make up for lost school time?
item.description: A massive task lies ahead for schools as they try to make up for teaching time lost during the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus, schools and children - what are the risks?
item.description: How much do children contribute to the spread of Covid?

item.title: Catcalling: The sisters who are making a noise to stop street harassment of women
item.description: Campaigners tell the BBC how they are working to address the root causes of violence against women.

item.title: Suffolk shipwreck find could be 'really rare'
item.description: Wooden sections of boats are found at Covehithe and on Thorpeness beach.

item.title: Covid: Jet2 customer asked to pay £1,000 to change flight dates
item.description: Olivia Sparnenn-Josh says she opted against a refund when her trip last year was cancelled.

item.title: Windmill immortalised by Turner returns to glory on Isle of Wight
item.description: Visitors will be able to clamber to the top of Bembridge Windmill once lockdown restrictions ease.

item.title: The Hebrides' wild swimming 'real-life' mermaid
item.description: Kate MacLeod can be found swimming in seas and lochs around the Western Isles in summer - and winter.
